Introduction

Hypospadias is the most common congenital anomaly of the external male genitalia and presents with a ventrally positioned urethral meatus.  It is typically an isolated finding and managed with surgical repair.

Pathogenesis



Differentiation and development of the external genitalia occur during weeks 8-15 of gestation (

figure 1
).  In male fetuses, androgens stimulate fusion of the urethral folds to form the ventral aspect of the penis and the penile raphe, which serve as the anterior wall of the urethra.



The mechanism of hypospadias is likely multifactorial due to genetic and environmental factors (eg, endocrine-disrupting chemicals), which result in incomplete fusion of the male urethral folds.  This leads to an abnormally positioned urethral meatus, often accompanied by chordee (ie, abnormal ventral penile curvature) and a dorsal hood appearance (ie, extra dorsal foreskin with deficient ventral foreskin).  The degree of fusion determines the location of the urethral meatus, and, in severe cases, the urethral opening is located proximally on the perineum or scrotum.

Epidemiology and risk factors 



Hypospadias is usually an isolated finding; it is not associated with renal abnormalities because the fetal kidneys develop prior to the formation of external genitalia.



Risk factors for isolated hypospadias include:



  • Advanced maternal age
  • Maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Family history of hypospadias
  • In utero exposure to endocrine-disrupting chemicals (eg, diethylstilbestrol)


In a minority of cases, hypospadias may indicate a difference in sex development (DSD) when severe or associated with other genital abnormalities (eg, cryptorchidism).  In addition, it may present along with a constellation of other organ abnormalities in the setting of WAGR syndrome (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, range of intellectual abilities) or CHARGE syndrome (coloboma, heart defect, atresia choanae, retarded growth, genital anomalies, ear abnormalities).

Clinical presentation



Hypospadias presents with a ventrally positioned urethral meatus and a blind-ending urethral pit at the normal location of the urethral meatus (ie, distal tip of the glans penis) (

figure 2
).  This is often accompanied by chordee and incomplete foreskin closure around the glans, giving the appearance of a dorsal hooded prepuce.



The severity of hypospadias is categorized primarily by the location of the urethral opening, with mild cases characterized by a urethral meatus within the glans, corona, or penile shaft and severe cases with a scrotal or perineal urethral meatus.  Severe cases may be accompanied by an underdeveloped glans.

Diagnosis and evaluation



Diagnosis of hypospadias is based on clinical examination.  Further work-up is not required in isolated and mild hypospadias (ie, urethral meatus within glans, corona, or penile shaft).



However, severe hypospadias (eg, scrotal/perineal urethral meatus) or the presence of an additional genital anomaly (eg, bilateral cryptorchidism) may indicate a DSD, such as undervirilization in a patient with an XY genotype or virilization in a patient with an XX genotype. These patients should undergo the following evaluation:



  • Karyotype to identify sex chromosomes
  • Pelvic ultrasonography to identify the presence/absence of a uterus
  • Sodium and potassium levels to look for adrenal insufficiency

Differential diagnosis



  • Epispadias (
    figure 3
    ):  an abnormal opening of the urethra on the dorsal surface of the penile shaft, often with dorsal penile curvature, and ventrally hooded prepuce.  It is typically associated with additional congenital anomalies such as bladder exstrophy.
  • Urethral fistula:  a second abnormal opening on the ventral aspect of the penile shaft in addition to a normally positioned urethral meatus (rather than a distal blind-ending urethral pit).  This can occur as a complication from surgery, or more rarely, as a congenital anomaly.

Management



Surgical correction is typically performed between age 6 and 18 months.  A requested circumcision should be deferred until after evaluation by a urologist because the foreskin may be used for hypospadias repair.

Prognosis and complications



Most children have positive functional and cosmetic outcomes after repair, including:



  • Normal urethral meatus position without deflection of the urinary stream and the ability to urinate from a standing position
  • Correction of any significant penile curvature to allow for future, pain-free erections that do not cause intercourse difficulties or fertility issues (ie, abnormal ejaculation)


Patients should be monitored for postsurgical complications and may need a revision if urethral fistula, stricture, and diverticulum occur.

Summary



Hypospadias (
